Introduction

BehÃ§et disease (BD), also known as BehÃ§et syndrome, is a chronic, relapsing, multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized classically by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, uveitis, and manifestations in other organ systems.  BD is generally thought of as a vasculitis, with vasculitis causing the majority, but not all, of its clinical manifestations.  BD is most prevalent along the ancient Silk Road from the Mediterranean basin through the Middle East to East Asia.

Pathophysiology



BD is an inflammatory disorder with an unknown etiology.  Vasculitis that notably affects both arterial and venous vasculature, as well as vessels of all sizes (small, medium, large), is thought to be responsible for most, but not all, clinical manifestations.  The pathogenesis remains incompletely understood but likely involves multiple factors that produce an exaggerated inflammatory response that damages tissue and organ systems.



  • Genetic predisposition:  A strong association with human leukocyte antigen (HLA) B51 suggests a genetic susceptibility.
  • Immune dysregulation:  Autoreactive T cells, increased neutrophil activity, dysregulated innate immune response, and autoantibody production are present in BD.
  • Endothelial dysfunction:  The vascular endothelial dysfunction seen in BD consists of endothelial-mediated vascular inflammation and thrombosis, as well as reduced endothelium-dependent, flow-mediated dilation (vascular dilation in response to increased blood flow).  These dysfunctions contribute to vasculitis that causes the majority of BD's clinical manifestations.
  • Bacterial and viral antigens:  Bacterial (eg, Streptococcus, Helicobacter pylori) and viral (eg, herpes simplex virus, parvovirus B19) antigens may cross-react with human proteins (eg, heat shock proteins), initiating or perpetuating the inflammatory process in BD.

Risk factors



  • Ethnicity:  The highest prevalence is observed in countries along the Silk Road, including Turkey, Iran, Iraq, Japan, Korea, China, and Saudi Arabia.  This geographic pattern reflects a higher prevalence of HLA-B51 in these areas.
  • Genetic background:  HLA-B51 positivity increases disease risk and severity.  Other genetic loci related to immune function have also been implicated.
  • Age and sex:  Most cases present in young adulthood (age 20-40).  Young men from the Middle East and Far Eastern Asia tend to have more severe disease.
  • Microbial exposure:  Recurrent exposure to certain microbes (eg, Streptococcus, Helicobacter pylori, herpes simplex virus) may trigger BD through molecular mimicry.

Pathology



Histologically, BD lesions often, although not always, demonstrate vasculitis involving capillaries, arteries, and veins of all sizes.  The vasculitis is a necrotizing leukocytoclastic, obliterative perivasculitis with venous thrombosis, as well as perivascular lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates.

Clinical presentation



BD is a multisystem disease that has a relapsing-remitting course, with significant variability in severity and organ involvement.  However, a feature common to all patients is painful, recurrent oral ulcerations (

image 1
).  Other features that occur frequently include recurrent genital ulcers, cutaneous lesions, and ocular disease.  Clinical manifestations are discussed in detail:



  • Oral ulcers:  The initial manifestation in most patients is oral aphthousâ€“like ulcerations.  The ulcers involve the oral mucosa and are painful.  Their size ranges from millimeters to 2 cm, and they have a white-yellow necrotic base with surrounding erythema.  These ulcers recur, usually >3 times a year.
  • Genital ulcers:  More than 75% of patients develop painful and recurrent genital ulcers during the course of the disease.  These ulcers typically occur on the vulva or scrotum and may cause scrotal scarring, a feature rarely seen in other conditions.
  • Skin lesions:  More than 75% of patients develop skin lesions, which encompass erythema nodosumâ€“like lesions, papulopustular eruptions, acneiform nodules, purpura, and pyoderma gangrenosumâ€“like lesions.  In addition, some patients exhibit a positive pathergy test, as evidenced by the development of an erythematous papule or pustule in response to skin trauma; this response is very specific for BD.
  • Ocular involvement:  Ocular disease occurs in 25%-75% of patients and is associated with high morbidity.  The most common manifestation is panuveitis (uveitis that involves the anterior and posterior uveal tracks) (
    figure 1
    ).  Hypopyon, or pus in the anterior chamber (
    figure 2
    ), can accompany severe anterior uveitis and is often associated with retinal vasculitis.
  • Arthritis:  Arthritis in BD is asymmetric, is nonerosive, and usually affects the medium and large joints (eg, knee, ankle, wrist).
  • Neurologic disease (neuro-BehÃ§et):  Inflammatory lesions (eg, in the cerebral cortex, brainstem, spinal cord) and cerebral vascular thrombosis result in focal neurologic deficits, headache, behavioral changes, and cognitive decline.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement:  Vasculitis of the small and large gastrointestinal vessels results in mucosal inflammation and ulcerations, as well as mesenteric ischemia, presenting as abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and vomiting.
  • Vascular involvement:  Arteries and veins of all sizes can be affected in BD.  Vascular disease presents as vessel stenosis, thrombosis (eg, vena cava occlusion, Budd-Chiari syndrome), aneurysm (eg, pulmonary artery aneurysm, causing hemoptysis), and hemorrhage.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria because no definitive laboratory test exists for BD.  Prior to applying the clinical criteria, however, other diseases should first be excluded (eg, oral and genital herpes, inflammatory bowel disease).  The clinical diagnostic criteria are as follows:



  • Recurrent oral aphthous ulcers (>3 times/year), plus â‰¥2 of the following:
    • Recurrent genital ulceration or scarring
    • Eye lesions (eg, uveitis, retinal vasculitis)
    • Skin lesions (eg, erythema nodosumâ€“like lesions, acneiform nodules)
    • Positive pathergy test, defined as â‰¥2-mm papule forming 24-48 hours after inserting a 20- to 25-gauge needle 5 mm into the skin.

Laboratory and imaging evaluation



Laboratory and imaging tests are not diagnostic of BD, but they are often performed during evaluation to assess organ involvement and to rule out other causes in the differential diagnosis.



  • Inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein):  May be elevated during active disease but are nonspecific.
  • Autoantibodies (eg, antinuclear antibody [ANA], antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody [ANCA]):  Typically negative in BD and can help exclude other autoimmune diseases (eg, lupus, ANCA-associated vasculitides).
  • Ophthalmologic evaluation (eg, slit-lamp examination, fluorescein angiography):  Used to evaluate ocular BD (eg, uveitis, retinal vasculitis).
  • Gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy:  Used to rule out inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which presents similarly to BD.
  • Imaging (eg, MRI, MR venography, CT scan, CT angiography, Doppler ultrasonography):  Used to evaluate neurologic (eg, parenchymal disease) and vascular (eg, aneurysms, deep venous thrombosis, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis) diseases in BD.

Differential diagnosis



  • Recurrent aphthous stomatitis:  Lesions are clinically and histologically indistinguishable from aphthous-like ulcers in BD (
    image 2
    ).  However, BD is associated with additional symptoms (eg, genital ulcerations, uveitis, cutaneous lesions [eg, erythema nodosumâ€“like lesions]) and tends to have more numerous lesions.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus:  Nearly 50% of lupus patients can have lip and oral mucosal involvement with plaques (discoid lesions), erythematous lesions, punched-out erosions, or ulcers.  However, the oral ulcers (except for discoid lesions) are usually painless, unlike the painful ulcers in BD.  In addition, ANA is positive in almost every patient; it is rarely positive in BD.
  • Herpes simplex infection:  Herpes can cause recurrent painful oral or genital ulcers, keratitis, and, sometimes, uveitis.  However, herpetic ulcers begin as a cluster of vesicles (
    image 3
    ), a feature not present in BD.
  • Sarcoidosis:  Sarcoidosis can present with uveitis, joint pain, and skin lesions (eg, erythema nodosum).  Lung involvement (eg, hilar adenopathy, reticular and nodular parenchymal lesions) is almost universal in sarcoidosis but is rare in BD.  Unlike in BD (in which patients universally have oral ulcers), oral ulcers are rare in sarcoidosis.
  • IBD:  Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis can present with aphthous-like oral ulcerations and uveitis, as well as abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and ulcerations in the gastrointestinal mucosa.  Lesions in Crohn disease may be distinguished from lesions in BD by the presence of granulomas on histologic examination and the presence of perianal disease (eg, fistulas).  Ulcerative colitis almost always has rectal involvement, a feature typically absent in BD.
  • Other vasculitides:  ANCA-associated vasculitides (eg, granulomatosis with polyangiitis [GPA], microscopic polyangiitis [MPA], and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis [EGPA]) can be distinguished from BD typically by the presence of ANCA and their characteristic features: upper/lower respiratory tract involvement and glomerulonephritis (GPA/MPA) and asthma/eosinophilia (EGPA).  Recurrent, painful oral ulcers are rare.

Management



Treatment is individualized and is based on organ involvement and disease severity.  BD is typically managed by a multidisciplinary team (eg, rheumatology, ophthalmology, neurology, gastroenterology)



  • Oral and genital ulcers

    • First-line:  Topical corticosteroid therapy (eg, triamcinolone 0.1% cream).
    • Refractory disease:  Oral corticosteroid therapy.
    • Prevention of recurrent ulcers:  Oral colchicine.
  • Cutaneous disease
    • Oral colchicine therapy, oral corticosteroid therapy.
  • Ocular involvement:
    • Anterior uveitis:  Topical corticosteroid therapy with a dilating agent (eg, scopolamine, cyclopentolate), which alleviates pupillary muscle spasms and prevents abnormal adhesion between the iris and lens (posterior synechiae).
    • Posterior uveitis:  High-dose systemic corticosteroid therapy with immunosuppressive therapy (eg, azathioprine).
  • Neurologic disease:
    • Azathioprine, high-dose systemic corticosteroid therapy with immunosuppressive therapy depending on the type and severity of neurologic involvement.
  • Vascular involvement:
    • High-dose systemic corticosteroid therapy with immunosuppressive therapy (eg, cyclophosphamide).
  • Arthritis:
    • Oral colchicine, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.
  • Gastrointestinal involvement:
    • High-dose systemic corticosteroid therapy with immunosuppressive therapy (eg, azathioprine).

Complications



  • Blindness from recurrent uveitis or retinal vasculitis.
  • Miscarriages from placental vasculitis.
  • Permanent neurologic deficits from nervous system involvement.
  • Gastrointestinal perforation or bleeding from intestinal ulcerations and inflammation.
  • Chronic pain and disability from arthritis and mucocutaneous disease.


Death occurs from rupture of pulmonary or coronary artery aneurysm.

Prognosis



There is no cure for BD.  With appropriate therapy, many patients achieve partial or complete remission; however, symptoms often relapse.



The prognosis of BD is variable, depending on the organ systems affected.  In general, patients exhibiting the following characteristics have a worse prognosis:



  • Ocular, neurologic, and vascular disease.
  • Male sex, early onset, and HLA-B51 positivity.

Summary



BehÃ§et disease is a chronic, relapsing, multisystem inflammatory disorder that is most prevalent in the region from the Mediterranean basin through the Middle East to East Asia.  The etiology is unknown; its pathogenesis involves a combination of genetic susceptibility and immune dysregulation.  Vasculitides affecting the arterial and venous vasculature and vessels of all sizes are thought to be responsible for most, but not all, of the clinical manifestations.



Clinically, BehÃ§et disease most commonly presents with oral aphthous-like ulcerations, scarring genital ulcerations, skin lesions (eg, erythema nodosumâ€“like lesions), and uveitis.  Other less common manifestations include gastrointestinal ulcerations, arthritis, neurologic disease (eg, focal parenchymal lesions), and vascular disease (eg, aneurysms).  The diagnosis is based on clinical diagnostic criteria (
